channel.title: Comments on: Next Steps (and new Opportunities)
channel.description: A Technical Community for IT Professionals

item.title: By: chopstik
item.dc:creator: chopstik
item.description: Yeah, maybe I read a bit more into this post (and I may have come across the developer vs programmer post). But I found the comment from your unnamed recruiter to be rather telling and one that is far too prevalent in much of the industry today - much to the detriment of, well, a lot of people and business (not to mention customers). Just my $.02...
item.content:encoded: Yeah, maybe I read a bit more into this post (and I may have come across the developer vs programmer post). But I found the comment from your unnamed recruiter to be rather telling and one that is far too prevalent in much of the industry today – much to the detriment of, well, a lot of people and business (not to mention customers). Just my $.02…

item.title: By: Eli Weinstock-Herman (tarwn)
item.dc:creator: Eli Weinstock-Herman (tarwn)
item.content:encoded:
I think you’re giving me more credit than I deserve on that one Chopstik (unless you also read the Developer vs Programmer post that’s been sitting on the sidelines the last couple months). I wasn’t trying to make any lasting points with this post, just make the announcement and do a quick jog down memory lane.

Also I think it’s important that we occasionally take time and look at some of what we have accomplished over the years (professionally and personally). I tend to be modest (or incredibly immodest in a sarcastic way) about my achievements and I have a bad memory. What this means is I often lose sight of the fact that I have had some really fun opportunities over the years. Sometimes we get so caught up in thinking about the future that we forget to reflect back over the successes, failures, and learning that we enjoyed along the way.

item.title: By: chopstik
item.dc:creator: chopstik
item.description: A very enlightening post, Tarwn, and (unfortunately) one to which I can relate more than I care to think about. There is a big difference between a developer and a programmer (that's how I view this difference, anyway) and, like you, I have found that I prefer to be more of a developer with the varying roles and responsibilities tied to it. I thank you for giving words to something that I've been otherwise unable to articulate very well.
item.content:encoded: A very enlightening post, Tarwn, and (unfortunately) one to which I can relate more than I care to think about. There is a big difference between a developer and a programmer (that’s how I view this difference, anyway) and, like you, I have found that I prefer to be more of a developer with the varying roles and responsibilities tied to it. I thank you for giving words to something that I’ve been otherwise unable to articulate very well.

item.title: By: LNBruno
item.dc:creator: LNBruno
item.content:encoded:
Pffft – don’t listen to ’em, Eli. We both know that, in the immortal words of Indiana Jones, “It’s not the years, honey, it’s the mileage.”

Bon chance!

item.title: By: Ted Krueger (onpnt)
item.dc:creator: Ted Krueger (onpnt)
item.description: I think Senior fits him then. He kis kind of old. Even looks older than us
item.content:encoded: I think Senior fits him then. He kis kind of old. Even looks older than us
